I know the premise to this movie is the little girl (Riley) moving into a new town, and struggling with life..and after some serious thinking, I think I have an idea of what this movie is going to be about. Alright, so..notice how in the parent's brains their emotions are all agreeing with one another, and conforming under one leader? While, inside Riley's mind, everything is bonkers for control, and who gets to do what? I think this whole movie is about how Disgust and Anger think they have the most control in this mind, and Joy and the others don't seem to like it. While Riley is battling the real-world, the emotions in her head battle for dominance as Riley's main emotion, the one she usually turns to. Maybe they all have their own unique way they think Riley should grow up, like Anger thinks Riley should be mean and nasty, but assertive to get what she wants, while Fear thinks she should be sheltered and afraid to step out of her comfort zone. I really do think this movie is going to revolve around some sort of power struggle, and either Anger or Disgust is going to be the antagonist; but not exactly doing bad things, just trying to live life the way they think could protect the girl they live inside of.

Just thinking is all..this movie has great possibilities, and I am sooo excited for it!

Keep in mind that Anger has the head seat for both the dad and the girl, and Sadness has head seat for the mom.

Also keep in mind how for the dad, when anger says "I don't wanna have to put the foot down," Fear stars trembling in fear.  However, after anger commands everyone to "put the foot down," fear and everyone else stats cheering for the "foot".

This is an obvious sign that fear and sadness controls this obviously dysfunctional family.

Most likely, the movie will tell the tale of this family's journey into love and compassion rather than fear and sadness.  No spoilers intended, but I wouldn't be surprised if Joy eventually takes head chair by the end of the movie for the whole family.

Whoa. A whole movie personifying the character's emotions and thought patterns. This movie's gonna have some layers.

I think it's very interesting how the environments these emotions are in all look different. Riley's mind has it's own and somewhat indescribable background to it as she is still trying to figure things out while the backgrounds of her parents' minds help to define the interactions between the emotions. I love howÂ the dad's mind is like HoustonÂ  bringing the astronauts home with a leader to whom everyone looks to in order to make a decision.Â  When he's got time off from dealing with a fight or flight situation, his emotions can hang out and have fun, but as soon as there's a problem,Â it turns into a bigger situation than it really is. Much like many type A people (myself included)Â we want things to be as simple as possible. So maybe in the mind of aÂ type A person, trying to solve aÂ confrontation would be likeÂ Houston trying to save the astronauts from hitting an asteroid.Â  In contrast, a type B personality (like the mother) is usually more free flowing and willing to adapt to a new situation. The mother's psychological landscape reminds me of a set of a talk show. Look at the curtain in the back and the desk,Â and those comfy looking chairs. The emotions all have obvious differences in personality and opinion much like the women on The View or The Talk. Even though Sadness has the head chair in the mother's head, her other emotions feel free to say how they feel about a problem and what they would do to solve it. Her inner monologue with her emotions really shines through as we see someone who is just as receptive to other people as well as her other, non-primary emotions.

I just love this, what a creative take on human emotion!! I think it's so cool how they show the differences between how children and adults manage their emotions. As you get older, itÂ can get easier to manage your emotions because you'll be more in tune with yourself andÂ just what you're feeling. Dealing with things in a calm, rational manner is something that can unifyÂ differing emotions.Â That's why they look the same in the mom and dad's heads, but not the girl's. In adolescents, like Riley, there's more of a divide between differing emotions. Also, in this movie, I really like that they show that people can sometimes be primarily motivated by a certain emotion. The dad responds with anger while the mom responds with sympathy. It's not that they only feel sadness or anger, it's just that everybody has a certain emotion thatÂ can trigger a more effective response in a "fight or flight" situation.

Two things I noticed:

1. From what we can see of the mom's "memories" (those colored orbs in the background), she seems to have a pretty calm demeanor. I don't see a single red orb back there.
2. This is actually quite perfect because the emotions in the parents' minds are a well-oiled machine. They're generally on the same level with each other and everything's in control. In Riley's growing mind, however, her emotions seem to be having a hard time getting along and maintaining peace and understanding each other.
